headline.print_headline: Smoking, Once Used to Reward, Faces a Ban in Mental Hospitals
headline.seo: Psychiatric Hospitals Alter Rules on Patient Smoking
headline.main: Smoking, Once Used to Reward, Faces a Ban in Mental Hospitals

docs.abstract: Change in Louisiana law will ban smoking in state's remaining psychiatric hospitals; shift removes tool that mental health professionals have used for decades as incentives or rewards for patients, and reflects growing effort by federal, state and other health officials to reverse course.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: After decades in which smoking by people with mental illness was supported and even encouraged, a move in Louisiana reflects a broader effort to reverse course.
docs.snippet: After decades in which smoking by people with mental illness was supported and even encouraged, a move in Louisiana reflects a broader effort to reverse course.

headline.print_headline: More Smoking Found By Mentally Ill People
headline.main: People With Mental Illness More Likely to Be Smokers, Study Finds

docs.abstract: Report from Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration finds that people with mental illness are 70 percent more likely to smoke cigarettes than people without mental illness.

keywords.value: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration
keywords.name: organizations

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: People with mental illness are 70 percent more likely to smoke cigarettes than people without mental illness, two federal health agencies reported Tuesday.
docs.snippet: People with mental illness are 70 percent more likely to smoke cigarettes than people without mental illness, two federal health agencies reported Tuesday.
